cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTVS GOVERNMENTPrinted for the War Cabinet. January 1941.SECRET. Copy No. 4 4W.M. (M)11th Conclusions.TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AMP KBIT.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 11 (41).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street,S.W.1, on Wednesday, January 29, 1941, at 5-30 p.m.Present:The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. C. R. Attlee, M.P.,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood,M.P., Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. A. Greenwood, M.P.,Minister without Portfolio.The Right Hon. Ernest bevin, M.P.,Minister of Labour and Minister ofNational Service.The Right Hon. Viscount Cranborne,Secretary of State for - DominionAffairs.The following were also present:The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.Sir Edward Bridges, Secretary.minute no.1.3.CONTENTS;Subject. , PChina .... ... JV-*'*'*-" "w .... .... .... 04Supply of Aircraft.The Balkans .... ........ g4Political and Military Situations.France .... u....Relations with the Vichy Government: Economic Negotiations.Italian East Africa .... .... .... ^Abyssinia:[22169]-Attitude to the.Emperor Haile Selassie.Position pf the White Civil Population. China. 1. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSupply of Foreign Secretary (W.P. (41) 13) on the supply of aircraft to China.Aircraft. On urgent representations from the United States authorities, we(Previous had agreed to release to China 100 aircraft from those allotted to reference: this country. The United States authorities now wanted us to SellW.M. (40) 308th these aircraft to an American Corporation, buying on behalf of theConclusions, Chinese Government. Was this procedure likely to involve us in minute 2.) difficulties with Japan ?The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs thought that therisk was probably less than it appeared. He thought that we should now make it clear to the United States authorities that, if the transaction went through in its present form and became known tothe Japanese, we should have to let it be known that we had acted in the manner proposed at the request of the United States Govern- -ment. He proposed that our representations in this matter, shouldbe made personally to President Roosevelt or Mr. Hull.After, a short discussion The War Cabinet approved the course proposed.The Balkans.Political andMilitarySituations.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 9thConclusions,Minute 3.)2. The War Cabinet had a short discussion on the positionin the Balkans. The death of General Metaxas was a serious loss.It seemed clear that some German infiltration into Bulgaria was taking place.The Prime Minister said that the position in this area was ananxious one and must be carefully watched. The Defence Com-mittee had under review the military position in the eastern mediterranean area.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.France.Relations withthe vichy government.EconomicNegotiations,(previous reference:W.M. (40) 290thConclusions,Minute 7.)3. The Foreign Secretary said that the "Vichy Government had made very wide demands in the economic discussions. their proposals had little relation to reality, and he had instructedSir Samuel Hoare to inform the French Ambassador in writingthat, while we would consider the French proposals as soon as theyhad been received in this country, we could not consider any con-cessions with regard to imports into Metropolitan France, beyondthe arrangements made for the relief of children in unoccupied france, and that for the moment the economic discussions should belimited to Morocco. Although Sir Samuelhad some doubts as tothe wisdom of this course, he (the Foreign Secretary) had thoughtthat we should make it plain to the Vichy Government that we werenot in a position to make large concessions such as they had in mind(telegrams Nos. 138 and 173 to Madrid),The War Cabinet approved this course. Great George Street, S.W. 1,January 29, 1941.Italian East 4. The War Cabinet were informed that a further telegramAfrica. had been received from General Smuts (No. 115) in regard to theAbyssinia. proposed announcement welcoming the reappearance of EthiopiaAttitude to the as an independent State and recognising the Emperor's claim to theEmperor Haile throne. General Smuts had suggested an alternative and -moreSelassie. cautiously worded statement.(previous reference: The Foreign Secretary handed round a revised draft, which.M. (41) 10th went some way to meet General Smuts' criticisms. This draft was conclusions, amended to read as follows : Minute 2.) lc jjjg j^ajes^y's Government would welcome the reappear-ance of an independent Ethiopian State and recognise theclaim of the Emperor Haile Selassie to the throne. TheEmperor has intimated to His Majesty's Government that hewill need outside assistance and guidance. His Majesty'sGovernment agree with this view and consider that any such assistance and guidance in economic and political matters should be the subject of international arrangement at theconclusion of peace. They reaffirm that they have themselves no territorial ambitions." In the meanwhile, the conduct of military operations by imperial forces in parts of Abyssinia will require temporarymeasures of military guidance and control. These will becarried out in consultation with the Emperor and will bebrought to an end as soon as the situation permits."The War Cabinet-(1) Invited the Foreign Secretary to submit a draft telegramfor the Prime Minister to send to General Smuts,incorporating the above revised draft announcement and making it plain that we could not go any further tomeet General Smuts' point of view.(2) Agreed that the announcement could be made in the revisedform as soon as General Smuts' reply had been received.Position of the jn discussion it was pointed out that no initiative had beenWhite Civil made to us by the Italian authorities in Abyssinia as to the safetyPopulation. cf the white civil population. But it seemed clear that we should(Previous not take any action in this matter except as part of terms ofReference: capitulation of the Italian forces in Abyssinia.W.M. (41) 10thConclusions,Minute 2.)
